factors.name: Repetitive Tasks
factors.evidence: Data entry clerks primarily perform repetitive data input tasks that can be easily automated with software tools.
factors.whyItMatters: High repetition in tasks increases vulnerability to automation.
mitigation: Learn advanced Excel functions to enhance data manipulation skills.
Explore automation tools to streamline current processes.
Develop skills in data cleaning and validation.

factors.name: Low Complexity
factors.evidence: The role relies heavily on basic typing and data entry with minimal decision-making involved.
factors.whyItMatters: Low complexity tasks are more likely to be replaced by AI-driven solutions.
mitigation: Engage in projects that require critical thinking and problem-solving.
Take on responsibilities that involve data interpretation rather than just entry.
Seek training in data analysis to increase task complexity.

factors.name: Attention to Detail
factors.evidence: While attention to detail is crucial, this skill can be supplemented by AI tools that check for errors.
factors.whyItMatters: AI can replicate attention to detail, reducing the unique value of this skill.
mitigation: Develop a data quality assurance process that includes human oversight.
Create documentation that outlines data quality standards.
Participate in cross-functional teams to understand broader data contexts.

factors.name: Skill Transferability
factors.evidence: Current skills in Excel and attention to detail can be leveraged in data stewardship or automation roles.
factors.whyItMatters: Transferable skills can help pivot to roles less susceptible to automation.
mitigation: Identify and pursue training in SQL and data management.
Network with professionals in adjacent roles to learn about their skills.
Engage in projects that allow for skill application in new contexts.

factors.name: Limited Career Growth
factors.evidence: Data entry roles often offer limited advancement opportunities, making it essential to seek new skills.
factors.whyItMatters: Stagnation in career growth can lead to higher job insecurity.
mitigation: Set a goal to transition to a more advanced role within the next year.
Seek mentorship from higher-level colleagues to understand career paths.
Attend workshops or webinars focused on career development.

roleAdjacencies.rationale: The role of Data Steward aligns well with your skills in data entry and attention to detail, while also offering a path to more complex data management tasks.

detail.title: Data Steward (AI Readiness)
detail.summary: Ensures organization data is clean, labeled, and legally compliant so it can be safely used to train or prompt AI models.
whyFutureReady: AI models are only as good as the data they are fed (Garbage In, Garbage Out).
Companies have massive 'data swamps' that need human judgment to organize.
Compliance and privacy regulations (GDPR, etc.) make unmanaged data a liability.

items: Audit datasets for errors, duplicates, and missing context.
Standardize naming conventions and metadata tags across systems.
Coordinate with subject matter experts to verify data accuracy.
Flag sensitive PII (Personally Identifiable Information) that must be redacted before AI processing.
Enforce access policies: who can see what data, and which models can ingest it.
Maintain a 'Data Dictionary' explaining what each field means.
Curate and chunk documents for Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems.
Test how well the AI retrieves answers from the knowledge base.
Update valid information and archive obsolete data to prevent hallucinations.

toolsExamples: SQL Clients (dbt knowledge is a plus)
Data Catalog tools (Collibra, Alation - enterprise level)

proofProjects.title: Clean Data Dictionary
whatYouBuild: A comprehensive guide to a specific internal dataset (e.g., Customer Orders)
Definitions for every column, valid value ranges, and sources of truth

proofProjects.title: Knowledge Base Audit
whatYouBuild: Review of 50 internal wiki pages or documents
Tagging system for 'AI Current', 'Outdated', 'Confidential'
Report on readiness for AI ingestion

proofProjects.title: PII Redaction Protocol
whatYouBuild: Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) for stripping customer names/emails from training data
Before/After examples of sanitized datasets

starterPlan30Days: Map the data: Create an inventory of one department's key spreadsheets and documents.
Clean one dataset: Take a messy 'dump' of data and standardize it (dates, names, formats).
Draft a tagging policy: Define 5-10 metadata tags that are essential for retrieval.
Test a query: Ask an AI chatbot questions about the data and note where it fails due to data quality.

roleAdjacencies.rationale: As an Automation Analyst, you can leverage your current skills in data entry while gaining new skills in process automation, making your role less susceptible to automation.
gapSkills: Basic data skills (spreadsheets, CSVs, SQL basics)

detail.title: Automation Analyst (Ops / RevOps)
detail.summary: Finds repetitive business processes and replaces them with reliable automations, dashboards, and SOPs—reducing busywork and errors.
whyFutureReady: Even with better AI, companies still need humans to define goals, constraints, and acceptance criteria.
Automation work ties directly to measurable outcomes (time saved, fewer errors, faster cycles).

items: Map workflows (handoffs, bottlenecks, error points).
Quantify impact (time/cost, failure rates).
Prioritize automation opportunities.
Automate routine tasks (routing, follow-ups, data sync, enrichment).

Write SOPs and train teams on the new workflow.

Ensure permissions, auditability, and data hygiene.
Iterate based on user feedback and changing requirements.

core: Basic data skills (spreadsheets, CSVs, SQL basics)

detail.title: Data Steward (AI Readiness)
detail.summary: Ensures organization data is clean, labeled, and legally compliant so it can be safely used to train or prompt AI models.
whyFutureReady: AI models are only as good as the data they are fed (Garbage In, Garbage Out).
Companies have massive 'data swamps' that need human judgment to organize.
Compliance and privacy regulations (GDPR, etc.) make unmanaged data a liability.

items: Audit datasets for errors, duplicates, and missing context.
Standardize naming conventions and metadata tags across systems.
Coordinate with subject matter experts to verify data accuracy.
Flag sensitive PII (Personally Identifiable Information) that must be redacted before AI processing.
Enforce access policies: who can see what data, and which models can ingest it.
Maintain a 'Data Dictionary' explaining what each field means.
Curate and chunk documents for Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems.
Test how well the AI retrieves answers from the knowledge base.
Update valid information and archive obsolete data to prevent hallucinations.

toolsExamples: SQL Clients (dbt knowledge is a plus)
Data Catalog tools (Collibra, Alation - enterprise level)

proofProjects.title: Clean Data Dictionary
whatYouBuild: A comprehensive guide to a specific internal dataset (e.g., Customer Orders)
Definitions for every column, valid value ranges, and sources of truth

proofProjects.title: Knowledge Base Audit
whatYouBuild: Review of 50 internal wiki pages or documents
Tagging system for 'AI Current', 'Outdated', 'Confidential'
Report on readiness for AI ingestion

proofProjects.title: PII Redaction Protocol
whatYouBuild: Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) for stripping customer names/emails from training data
